datafield.subfield: Comparing Submillimeter Polarized Emission with Near-infrared Polarization of Background Stars for the Vela C Molecular Cloud

We present a large-scale combination of near-infrared (near-IR) interstellar polarization data from background starlight with polarized emission data at submillimeter wavelengths for the Vela C molecular cloud. The near-IR data consist of more than 6700 detections probing a range of visual extinctions between 2 and $20\,\mathrm{mag}$ in and around the cloud. The submillimeter data were collected in Antarctica by the Balloon-borne Large Aperture Submillimeter Telescope for Polarimetry. This is the first direct combination of near-IR and submillimeter polarization data for a molecular cloud aimed at measuring the “polarization efficiency ratio” (${R}_{\mathrm{eff}}$), a quantity that is expected to depend only on grain-intrinsic physical properties. It is defined as ${p}_{500}/({p}_{I}/{\tau }_{V})$, where p (500) and p ( )I( ) are polarization fractions at $500\,\mu {\rm{m}}$ and the I band, respectively, and ${\tau }_{V}$ is the optical depth. To ensure that the same column density of material is producing both polarization from emission and from extinction, we conducted a careful selection of near-background stars using 2MASS, Herschel, and Planck data. This selection excludes objects contaminated by the Galactic diffuse background material as well as objects located in the foreground. Accounting for statistical and systematic uncertainties, we estimate an average ${R}_{\mathrm{eff}}$ value of 2.4 ± 0.8, which can be used to test the predictions of dust grain models designed for molecular clouds when such predictions become available. The ratio ${R}_{\mathrm{eff}}$ appears to be relatively flat as a function of the cloud depth for the range of visual extinctions probed.

The average polarization efficiency ratio ({R}_{\mathrm{eff}}\ ={p}_{500}/({p}_{I}/{\tau }_{V})) is found to be 2.4 ± 0.8 for cloud visual extinctions between \sim 2\,\mathrm{mag} and \sim 20\,\mathrm{mag}. This value can be used to test dust grain models designed specifically for the environment found inside molecular clouds
We have examined the dependence of {R}_{\mathrm{eff}} on cloud visual extinction, and we find no statistically significant deviations from a flat trend over the range of extinctions probed

The polarization efficiency ratio is shown to vary significantly if far-background objects (contaminated by the diffuse background ISM) are included. This effect highlights the importance of selecting suitable stellar objects, such that the columns of material probed by polarized extinction and emission are similar. Nevertheless, we find that at higher cloud extinctions, the effect of the background contamination is negligible, since the relative contribution from the molecular cloud itself is dominant

Photometric errors or uncertainties associated with assumptions used in the {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} calculation method (Section, 4.2: #apjaa62a7s4-2): The statistical uncertainties \sigma {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} derived solely through propagation of errors (from 2MASS J, H, and Ks magnitudes) typically range between 0.3 and 0.8\,\mathrm{mag}. These correspond to lower limits for the true uncertainties, which may also be affected by systematic effects such as variations in grain properties (which influence the total-to-selective extinction ratio and consequently the conversion between E(J-{K}_{s}) and {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}}, as discussed in Section, 4.2: #apjaa62a7s4-2) and uncertainties in intrinsic colors. The combined statistical and systematic uncertainties in {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} are \sim 1.5\,\mathrm{mag}, as discussed in Section, 5.2: #apjaa62a7s5-2 and in Appendix D

Stars distributed over a range of distances and thus possibly contaminated by far-background material: It is possible to estimate statistically the fraction of stars in our wide photometric field sample that are located respectively in the foreground and background, by combining a simple model of the Galactic stellar distribution with information regarding the 2MASS sensitivity for our sample. A standard stellar distribution model (Bahcall, 1986: #apjaa62a7bib8) gives the total number density of stars ntot as a function of the Galactic radius r and perpendicular distance from the Galactic plane z: \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{n}_{\mathrm{tot}}(r,z)=n({R}_{0}){e}^{-z/{z}_{0}}{e}^{-(r-{R}_{0})/h},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 4 } \end{equation*} where R0 is the distance from the Sun to the Galactic center (\approx 8\,\mathrm{kpc}), n({R}_{0}) is the number density of stars in the solar neighborhood (\approx 0.13 stars/pc3), z0 is the scale height (\approx 250\, pc), and h is the disk scale length (\approx 3.5\,\mathrm{kpc}). This equation can be rewritten in terms of d, defined as the distance from the Sun along LOS, using {r}^{2}={R}_{0}^{2}+{d}^{2}-2{{dR}}_{0}\cos (l) and z=d\sin (b) (where l and b are the cloud's Galactic longitude and latitude, respectively taken as 266^\circ and 1^\circ). The total number of stars in a field of view of area A(d) may be found by integrating the function {N}_{\mathrm{tot}}(d)=A(d){n}_{\mathrm{tot}}(d) along d. Finally, the actual number of stars detected by 2MASS is given by Ndet(d) = {f}_{p}(d){N}_{\mathrm{tot}}(d), where fp(d) is the total fraction of stars that are detectable given the 2MASS sensitivity, as a function of distance d (see below).Using standard methods (e.g., Santos et al : #apjaa62a7bib72), we find that for the wide photometric field the photometric completeness limits are given by ({J}_{\mathrm{cl}},{H}_{\mathrm{cl}},{{Ks}}_{\mathrm{cl}}) = (15.3, 14.5, 14.3). The J and H values are slightly smaller than the canonical 2MASS limits (given by 15.8 and 15.1, respectively

2006: #apjaa62a7bib75), because our sample selects only stars with 2MASS photometric quality and excludes points outside the reddening band (see Section, 4.2: #apjaa62a7s4-2). With these completeness limits (referred to as {m}_{\mathrm{cl}}), the maximum distance {d}_{\max } at which a star of a given spectral type and luminosity class can be detected may be obtained through {m}_{\mathrm{cl}}-{M}_{\lambda }=5\mathrm{log}({d}_{\max })-5+{A}_{\lambda }, where Mλ is the intrinsic magnitude (Koornneef,: #apjaa62a7bib46
Wegner,: #apjaa62a7bib81) and Aλ is the extinction at each band (converted to AV using canonical relations

Fitzpatrick, 1999: #apjaa62a7bib25). Combining {d}_{\max } with the information on the typical fractions for each stellar type (e.g., Ledrew, 2001: #apjaa62a7bib51), we find that the fraction function for our sample is approximately given by {f}_{p}(d)={e}^{-0.0014d}+0.0018. To derive this curve, we also use models of Galactic extinction from Amôres & Lépine (,: #apjaa62a7bib2) to estimate the extinctions of diffuse matter as a function of distance toward saturating extinction levels at high distances (\approx 20\,\mathrm{kpc}) given by this model (\approx 3.3\,\mathrm{mag}) do not agree with nearby off-cloud extinctions derived from Planck for the same Galactic latitudes (\approx 6\,\mathrm{mag}). This difference might be due to increased submillimeter optical depth per unit column density near the Galactic plane (see Section, 4.3: #apjaa62a7s4-3) or diffuse molecular material not being accounted for in the Amôres & Lépine (,: #apjaa62a7bib2) model. We scaled the extinction values from Amôres & Lépine (,: #apjaa62a7bib2) by a factor of 1.8 so that the saturating AV values at high distances correspond to the values found by Planck. Note that even without this scaling, the mean far-background {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} values found for the wide photometric field are still fairly large, as will be discussed below.The function Ndet(d) gives the total number of detectable stars as a function of distance, as shown in Figure, 12: #apjaa62a7f12. Giants and supergiants in general are bright enough to be detected at large distances (\gt 10\,\mathrm{kpc}). The mean stellar distance of the background stars according to this model is \sim 4.4\,\mathrm{kpc}, with a broad distribution peaking at \sim 1.3\,\mathrm{kpc}. At this mean distance, the AV according to the models is 3.2\,\mathrm{mag}. If the extinctions from Amôres & Lépine (,: #apjaa62a7bib2) are not scaled to match Planck (as described above), then we find that the AV at the mean stellar distance is \approx 2.1\,\mathrm{mag}. The range of stellar extinctions 2.1\mbox{--}3.2\,\mathrm{mag} is consistent with the mean {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} for the wide photometric field off-cloud stars (black histogram in Figure, 7: #apjaa62a7f7, top left). Integrating the curve of Figure, 12: #apjaa62a7f12, we find that the fractions of expected foreground and background detected stars are respectively 6% and 94%. It is also worth pointing out that the fraction of background stars located beyond 2\,\mathrm{kpc} is \approx 59 \%, showing that a significant fraction of the detected stellar sample is expected to be located in the far background. Thus, {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} is probably significantly affected by background material, which is shown to be nonnegligible in the general direction of Vela C (see Section, 4.5: #apjaa62a7s4-5 and Appendix B)

Beam averaging over cloud and clumps: The difference between the finite Herschel beam and the stellar pencil beam introduces an additional source of spread in the {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} values (see below)

The number of {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} distributions (Nd) between {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{cl}}=0 and 10\,\mathrm{mag}, which naturally affects the {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{cl}} bin widths for each histogram of Figure, 15: #apjaa62a7f15. For larger Nd, the number of points available for the GL fits inside each histogram decreases. For the particular case shown in Figure, 8: #apjaa62a7f8, we chose {N}_{{\rm{d}}}=18 (and therefore Δ{A}_{V}^{\mathrm{cl}} \approx \,0.56\,\mathrm{mag} for each distribution). To account for systematics, values of Nd = 18, 14, and 10 were used

The bin sizes Δ{A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} for each distribution, which are defined according to the following relation: {\rm{\Delta }}{A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}}={R}_{\mathrm{bin}}/(\mathrm{log}{N}_{\mathrm{hist}}), where {N}_{\mathrm{hist}} is the total number of elements in a given histogram and {R}_{\mathrm{bin}} is a proportionality factor that may be varied. This allows the bin sizes to decrease or increase if the number of elements is, respectively, higher or lower. In Figure, 8: #apjaa62a7f8, we used {R}_{\mathrm{bin}}=5\,\mathrm{mag}. Here, values of {R}_{\mathrm{bin}}=3, 5, and 7\,\mathrm{mag} are used

The maximum {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} to truncate the distributions in order to apply the GL fits. In each histogram of Figure, 15: #apjaa62a7f15, only the shaded area is used in the GL fits, because the drop in the number of stars for higher {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} is not accounted for in Equation (, 2: #apjaa62a7eqn2) (the precise position where this drop occurs is not important for our purposes). Therefore, a maximum {A}_{V}^{\mathrm{st}} needs to be chosen. In Figure, 8: #apjaa62a7f8, we set this maximum limit to be the position of the first bin after the highest peak of the histogram ({N}_{\max }=1). Here, values of {N}_{\max }=0, 1, and 2 are used
